results.title: Forgotten people
results.creator_credit: Barry Merton and Mathias, Kenyon and Merton Pictures
results.brief_description:
Shows the work of the Aborigines Advancement League particularly of Pastor Doug Nicholls and Bill Onus. They visit the settlements of Rumbaland, Robinvale and Dareton, showing the primitive conditions in which the aborigines are forced to live. Government housing is not provided at a sufficient rate. This film stresses the need for more positive action.
Sponsored by the Aborigines Advancement League (Victoria) in the wake of the 1967 Referendum, and featuring two of the League’s founding members in Nicholls and Onus.

results.title: 'For better, for worse'
results.brief_description: Taking an average viewer as its hero this cartoon demonstrates satirically how television can be a pleasure and a source of information or, if taken in too large a dose, can mesmerize and engulf the viewer. It contains some inventive gags, lively animation and genial humour.

results.title: Natural Glass
results.creator_credit: John King, Derek Wright and New Zealand National Film Unit
results.brief_description: Looks at a one-man revival of “natural” glass-making in New Zealand, contrasting the delicacies of glass making by one man with his normal job as a worker in a natural gas field.

results.title: Flying menace
results.creator_credit: W. H. Shepherd, John Martin-Jones and Australian Commonwealth Film Unit
results.brief_description: Describes the life cycle of the fruit fly, and the destruction it causes among Australian fruit. Illustrates the precautions being taken by the Department of Agriculture in checking the spread of the menace and shows how farmers should destroy contaminated fruit.
results.creator_credit_for_label: W. H. Shepherd, John Martin-Jones and Australian Commonwealth Film Unit

results.title: First aid
results.brief_description: A film of historic interest: an official training film produced for the War department in three parts. Part 1: emergency treatment of bleeding wounds, including self-administration. Covers the arterial system, pressure points and application of tournequets. Part 2: emergency treatment of broken bones. Part 3: covers methods of removing the wounded.

Part 3: covers methods of removing the wounded.

results.title: The Field day
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Adults Learning”.
A teaching aid to promote group discussion on the problems of the adult learning process in the management-staff relations. Shows a gathering at a rural agricultural field day. The film seems to be pointing out that resistance to new ideas is hard to overcome.

results.creator_credit: Ian Dunlop, Richard Mason, Loch Townsend, Malcolm Otton, Maslyn Williams, Stanley Hawes and Australian Commonwealth Film Unit

results.title: Farewell to childhood
results.creator_credit: Julian Roffman, Herbert Kerkow and Mental Health Film Board
results.brief_description: Shows common problems of adolescents and their parents. A moody 15 year-old girl clashes with her parents when they frustrate her efforts to “run her own life”. Mistakes by the parents, such as scolding her in front of her young escort, widen the rift between parents and daughter. Conditions improve when the girl’s teacher arranges a thorough discussion of adolescent problems, bringing more tolerance to both sides.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Julian Roffman, Herbert Kerkow and Mental Health Film Board

results.title: Explosives: the two metre lifeline
results.creator_credit: David Plummer, Donald Crombie, Milton Ingerson and South Australian Film Corporation
results.brief_description:
In this 1974 film, the use of comedy and narrative drama are employed to demonstrate the correct handling of explosives and detonators. Produced by the South Australian Film Corporation for the South Australian Mines Department, the film shows three people who handle explosives in the course of an ordinary day: a farmer removing tree stumps from his paddock, an opal miner in Coober Pedy and a ‘powder monkey’ on a road construction crew.

Introduced by a stereotypical ‘Aussie bloke’ drinking a beer at the pub, the film follows the three protagonists through their separate stories, as the narrator points out the mistakes and correct methods in their techniques. Demonstrating a casual, light-hearted approach to safety instruction, this film is a humorous presentation filled with expletives and colloquial terms, aimed to speak to workers on their level.

The colour is faded throughout the film.

Please note: As this is an archival work, the content does not reflect current practice or standards. Professional advice for up-to-date safety practices should be sought from the appropriate contemporary authority.

results.title: Exploration 1770, reviewed 1970
results.creator_credit: Tim Reid, Frank Bagnall, Stanley Dalby and Australian Commonwealth Film Unit
results.brief_description: Contrasts Captain Cook’s observations on his voyage along the eastern coast of Australia in 1770 with scenes of the Royal Visit in 1970 and bicentenary celebrations including re-enactments of his landings. Suitable for upper primary and lower secondary levels.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Tim Reid, Frank Bagnall, Stanley Dalby and Australian Commonwealth Film Unit
